page.title: 17LANDSCAPE IN MARSHFIELD
page.content: The village centre has changed little since about 1750. It contains a number of fine old buildings, with later development, all set in open rolling countryside. The High Street, with a Market Place at the east end, is the main thoroughfare with parallel lanes behind the buildings. Other lanes lead into the country and open fields, grassland and woodland. Outlying farms, barns and boundary walls are all built of local Cotswold stone. In the village is one Grade I listed building, the 15th century Parish Church, and several Grade II 'star', including the Manor, Home Farm Barn and its Dovecote, the Almshouses of 1612-1619, nos. 14 and 123 High St, Marshfield House (the former Vicarage of 1730) and a chapel, now the Legion Hall. Most buildings in the High Street are listed Grade II.
